This video is just playing games with semantics as click bait, and then doing a poor job of clarifying the misunderstanding that it created. Changing the angle of the laser doesn't "move" anything, it just recreates a new spot of light in a different location. Recreating a spot of light in two locations with different photons is not the same as something moving between the two locations. This is equivalent to having two light bulbs on the moon (or on earth, or anywhere else), with first light being on and the second being off. By switching the first light off, and the second on (within a time period shorter than that required for light to travel between the two bulb locations), you can claim that your spot of light "moved" between the two locations faster than the speed of light. In reality nothing actually moved between the bulbs. The photons coming from the second bulb are different from the photons which came from the first bulb. (This was the point of pixel analogy.) The conceptual confusion comes from thinking of the laser beam as a solid rod extending from the earth to the moon. Assuming you had a perfectly rigid and unbreakable rod of that length, it would be impossible to change its angle rapidly enough to make the tip move faster than the speed of light.

Thought provoking but I think it falls short.  Special relativity pretty much squashes everything he talks about.  Comments have already been made about the particles of the laser beam not traveling faster than the speed of light but special relativity doesn’t just assert that physical objects can’t move faster than the speed of light, special relativity shows that nothing can move through space at over the speed of light, INCLUDING information.  The idea that I could signal an astronaut at point A and then signal a different astronaut at point B faster than the speed of light implies that I could have causal impact on events that, from different points of reference (i.e. viewers with different velocities traveling in different directions), have an ambiguous order in time.
I was a bit stumped by the pixel idea but I think time is the issue here too.  If a pixel at point A is illuminated at T1 and then Pixel B is illuminated at T2, where Point A and B are far enough apart that light could not have traveled between them in the time between T1 and T2 you get the same order ambiguity. That is, observers from different reference points will disagree on whether Pixel A or B was illuminated first.  So in this pixel example I don’t think that you would succeed in creating an image/information that is intelligible from all points of reference.  That is, you will have succeeded in creating a host of individual pixel events with ambiguous time orders.
